comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: AH Runge was fire marshal of the State of Dakota in the 1910s. George Consider Hale (1850-1923) was fire chief in Kansas City (1882-1902), and an inventor of fire safety equipment. Joseph Johnson was Fire Commissioner in New York City, 1911-1913: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Johnson_(FDNY_Commissioner)

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The Firemen's Memorial in Riverside Park, New York, was dedicated on September 5, 1913. These men were part of the national delegation in attendance on that occasion.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: pennylrichardsca: Thanks for giving us more information about these folks.  We'll add it to the source data next time we update the record.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I started biographies on Hale and Runge in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Consider_Hale en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_H._Runge August H. Runge (February 12, 1852 - 1921) was the Fire Chief of Minneapolis for 20 years. He then became the Fire Marshal for North Dakota and was involved in a North Dakota Supreme Court case Runge v. Glerum that forbade interfering with a fire marshal or police officer while on duty.
